posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: We're experiencing momentary and unpredictable latency increases and are looking for insights from teams that use Photon Vision to identify potential causes. We've made some adjustments to our setup that might be contributing, such as setting the number of threads to 7 (below our coprocessor's maximum of 8) and enabling the experimental "turbo button." Additionally, we're publishing a boolean topic `/photonvision/use_new_cscore_frametime` to enable a new frame grabber behavior. While these changes aim to improve performance, they may introduce variability in latency. We're curious if enabling this feature has caused similar issues for others and whether teams have experienced misalignment when using it.

link_counts.title: Ingest wpilib!7609 and add turbo button by mcm001 · Pull Request #1662 · PhotonVision/photonvision · GitHub

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Do you have a wpilog file handy of this? I’d be interested to see time sync statistics.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: It is not letting me attach WPILog files. I will share a drive link here.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: The primary camera we are using is "reef," I believe. That one does all the processing we need.

link_counts.title: MXVIII - Log Files from SMR - Google Drive

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
From the log file FRC_20250405_141305_TNKN_Q68.wpilog, time synchronization appears to remain active despite the sequence number dropping to 0 between 264 and 274 seconds. After resuming, the sequence restarts from 15217 to 15218. This behavior likely stems from the logic in the CpuImageProcessor.java file, specifically lines around 89C1-L94C10 in the PhotonVision repository.  

Do your PhotonVision logs frequently display "Input was empty!" messages?

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: I’m not sure where to find that information, would it be logged in the driver station?

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Extremely importantly, you can find it on the PhotonVision dashboard. There should be a button to download logs, which you can then look at. You can also view them live, but that might not be as helpful if this isn't a currently occurring issue.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: Alright. I’ll try to get these as soon as possible.

posts.name: HighClimber1768
posts.cooked: We had this exact problem and solved it by not allowing photonvision to process more than five April tags at a time and disabling the WPI Lib watchdog. Thanks to team 190 for helping us with this problem.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: We will try these fixes. Thanks! Still working on getting the logs.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked:
photonvision-logs.zip (119.5 KB)  
Here they are. Yes, there are, however, a lot of instances where it says “input was empty.”

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
in photonvision-journalctl.txt, the lines from KernelLogLogger are of particular interest to me. For example, I see entries like:

Oct 31 22:28:08 java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:07.638067+00:00 reef kernel: usb 4-1: USB disconnect, device number 3  
Oct 31 22:28:08 java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:07.641367+00:00 reef kernel: uvcvideo 4-1:1.1: Failed to resubmit video URB (-19).  
Oct 31 22:28:08 java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:07.954778+00:00 reef kernel: usb 4-1: new high-speed USB device number 4 using ehci-platform  
Oct 31 22:28:08 java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:08.124742+00:00 reef kernel: usb 4-1: New USB device found, idVendor=0c45, idProduct=6366, bcdDevice= 1.00  
Oct 31 22:28:08 java[659]: [2024-10-31 22:28:08] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:28:08.124758+00:00 reef kernel: usb 4-1: New USB device strings: Mfr=2, Product=1, SerialNumber=3  

And also entries like:  
Oct 31 22:41:07 java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:07] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:06.762977+00:00 reef kernel: usb usb6-port1: disabled by hub (EMI?), re-enabling...  
Oct 31 22:41:07 java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:07] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:06.762995+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: USB disconnect, device number 2  
Oct 31 22:41:07 java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:07] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:06.766288+00:00 reef kernel: uvcvideo 6-1:1.1: Failed to resubmit video URB (-19).  
Oct 31 22:41:07 java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:07] [Camera - USBFrameProvider - reef_cam] [ERROR] Error grabbing image: timed out getting frame  

Some time later:  
Oct 31 22:41:11 java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:11] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:10.609634+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: New USB device found, idVendor=0c45, idProduct=6366, bcdDevice= 1.00  
Oct 31 22:41:11 java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:11] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:10.609646+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: New USB device strings: Mfr=2, Product=1, SerialNumber=3  
Oct 31 22:41:11 java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:11] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:10.609647+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: Product: Arducam OV9782 USB Camera  
Oct 31 22:41:11 java[661]: [2024-10-31 22:41:11] [General - KernelLogLogger] [DEBUG] 2024-10-31T22:41:10.609648+00:00 reef kernel: usb 6-1: Manufacturer: Arducam Technology Co.

This isn’t super helpful – it doesn’t rule out much – but it’s good to confirm that the camera itself is disconnecting from your coprocessor. Things to investigate might include a loose USB connection, ESD damage to the camera or orange pi, and power supply quality.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: I will bring this up. Thank you.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: I was told there are no apparent issues with the camera being damaged. Still confirming if it’s a loose USB, but it’s unlikely. Would you happen to know if there’s anything else that could be causing this?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
It's important to remember that PhotonVision doesn't fully control the camera stack, from photons to the RIO. Its functionality depends on the camera hardware, USB connection, USB drivers, Camera Driver, CSCore abstracted components, and the Linux operating system to provide information about connected cameras and pixel color assignments. Your logs indicate that the Linux kernel is struggling to communicate with the camera, preventing it from supplying frames to PhotonVision.  

Several potential causes exist, but one key point to consider is that if the issue stemmed from the Linux kernel or the driver itself, it would appear in the logs of everyone using it. Since this particular error is rare, your team's unique setup is likely the reason for the difference.  

If you're using the standard PhotonVision Orange Pi 5 image without software modifications, most aspects of your system stack should align with others'. However, unique factors in your setup could include whether the USB cable is securely seated, how the cable is connected and routed between the camera and board, or specific solder joints on any board components.  

Therefore, the best course of action is to inspect these areas, as they are likely causing the unique issue you're encountering.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Some cameras have a Ferrite noise filter, while others do not.
